metadata.feature_description: Group similar activities together in the stream

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify Activity Stream module loads and is accessible

steps.action: Navigate to Community page where Activity Stream is displayed
steps.expected: Activity Stream module loads and displays activity items
steps.actual: Activity Stream module loaded successfully with posts, badges, privileges, and other activity types visible

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify activity filtering works (prerequisite for grouping)

steps.expected: Dropdown opens showing various activity type filter options
steps.actual: Dropdown opened showing filter options including Posts, Links, Photos, Privilege Earned, Badge, etc.

steps.expected: Stream filters to show only privilege earned activities
steps.actual: Stream filtered successfully showing only privilege earned activities (Edit article metadata, Edit own comments, Create articles)

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify grouping logic exists in backend

steps.action: Review code for grouping implementation in ActivityStreamParser.cs and GroupedJournalControl.js
steps.expected: Code shows grouping logic for similar activities
steps.actual: Code review confirmed: (1) CountSimilarEntries parameter controls grouping in SQL queries, (2) GroupedJournalViewModel.cs handles grouped user display, (3) others-grouped-journal CSS class handles UI rendering of 'X and Y others' text, (4) GetGroupedJournalBasic and GetGroupedJournalDetailed API endpoints support expanding grouped items

observations: The 'Activity Stream Grouping' feature is an automatic backend mechanism, not a user-configurable display option. The feature description mentions 'UI Location: Activity Stream > Display Options' but no such explicit Display Options UI exists.

Grouping occurs automatically when multiple different users perform the same privileged activity (e.g., multiple users earning the same privilege). This displays as 'User X and Y others also earned this privilege'.
The current test data shows activities from a single user (Anonymous/host), so no grouped entries are visible. Grouping requires multiple users performing the same action.

Code analysis confirms the grouping logic is implemented via: CountSimilarEntries parameter in JournalItemsQuery, SimilarCount field in SQL stored procedures, GroupedJournalControl.js for UI interactions, and ActivityStreamParser.cs for rendering grouped entries.
The 'others-grouped-journal' CSS class and GetGroupedJournalBasic/GetGroupedJournalDetailed API endpoints are used to display and expand grouped activities.
Suggested test scenarios like 'Group/Ungroup activities' and 'Expand grouped activities' are not user-controllable actions - grouping happens automatically based on activity data patterns.
